title: Authors and Citation
text: Youzhi Yu. Author, maintainer. Trent Buskirk. Author, thesis advisor.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Yu Y, Buskirk T (2022). ggDoubleHeat: Heatmap-Like Visualization Tool. R package version 0.1.1, https://pursuitofdatascience.github.io/ggDoubleHeat/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {ggDoubleHeat: A Heatmap-Like Visualization Tool},   author = {Youzhi Yu and Trent Buskirk},   year = {2022},   note = {R package version 0.1.1},   url = {https://pursuitofdatascience.github.io/ggDoubleHeat/}, }

title: A Heatmap-Like Visualization Tool
text: ggDoubleHeat package ggplot2 extension provides visualization data two different sources modified heat map. functions package named geom_heat_*(). regular heat map, can made using geom_tile() ggplot2, contains three dimensions (variables). geom_heat_*(), however, can express four dimensions data single plot.

title: A Heatmap-Like Visualization Tool
text: Please install released version ggDoubleHeat CRAN : Alternatively, can install latest development version Github :

title: A Heatmap-Like Visualization Tool
text: demonstration purposes, built-dataset pitts_tg used illustrate basic usage package. pitts_tg dataset collects 30-week period COVID-related Google & Twitter incidence rate 9 different categories Pittsburgh Metropolitan Statistical Area (MSA). complete information dataset, please type ?pitts_tg console. Let’s start geom_heat_grid():  Now changing geom_heat_grid() geom_heat_circle():  Let’s use geom_heat_tri():  make things bit colorful, popular emoji given week given category respective Pittsburgh Twitter daily sample files rendered component heatgrid using ggtext. following code commented, takes minutes generate. like run , just simply uncomment code. generated heatgrid emojis attached image. image Note: pitts_emojis Emoji metadata built ggDoubleHeat. Another thing worth noting grids Emoji, reason Emoji Unicode Twitter sample file.
code: library(ggDoubleHeat) library(ggplot2) pitts_tg ## # A tibble: 270 x 6 ##    msa         week week_start category          Twitter  Google ##    <chr>      <int> <date>     <chr>               <dbl>   <dbl> ##  1 Pittsburgh     1 2020-06-01 Covid              0.965  0.681   ##  2 Pittsburgh     1 2020-06-01 General Virus      0.538  0.0982  ##  3 Pittsburgh     1 2020-06-01 Masks              0.466  0.117   ##  4 Pittsburgh     1 2020-06-01 Sanitizing         0.0561 0.127   ##  5 Pittsburgh     1 2020-06-01 Social Distancing  0.294  0.0386  ##  6 Pittsburgh     1 2020-06-01 Symptoms           0.0457 0.0770  ##  7 Pittsburgh     1 2020-06-01 Tests              0.0130 0.00415 ##  8 Pittsburgh     1 2020-06-01 Treatment          0.0459 0.0376  ##  9 Pittsburgh     1 2020-06-01 Working            0.295  0.160   ## 10 Pittsburgh     2 2020-06-08 Covid              1.01   0.707   ## # ... with 260 more rows ggplot(data = pitts_tg, aes(x = week, y = category)) +   geom_heat_grid(outside = Google, inside = Twitter) +   ggtitle("Pittsburgh Google & Twitter Incidence Rate (%) Comparison") ggplot(data = pitts_tg, aes(x = week, y = category)) +   geom_heat_circle(outside = Google, inside = Twitter) +   ggtitle("Pittsburgh Google & Twitter Incidence Rate (%) Comparison") ggplot(data = pitts_tg, aes(x = week, y = category)) +   geom_heat_tri(lower = Google, upper = Twitter) +   ggtitle("Pittsburgh Google & Twitter Incidence Rate (%) Comparison") # install.packages("ggtext") # library(ggtext) #  # ggplot(data = pitts_tg, aes(x = week, y = category)) + #   geom_heat_grid(outside = Google, inside = Twitter) + #   # rendering emojis using "richtext" #   annotate("richtext", x = rep(c(1:30), 9), y = rep(1:9, each = 30),  #            label = pitts_emojis, label.color = NA, fill = NA, size = 0.3) + #   ggtitle("Pittsburgh Google & Twitter Incidence Rate (%) Comparison")

title: Heatcircle — geom_heat_circle
text: heatcircle geom used create two concentric circles use luminance show values two sources plot.

title: Heatcircle — geom_heat_circle
code: geom_heat_circle(   outside,   outside_name = NULL,   outside_colors = c("#FED7D8", "#FE8C91", "#F5636B", "#E72D3F", "#C20824"),   inside,   inside_name = NULL,   inside_colors = c("gray100", "gray85", "gray50", "gray35", "gray0"),   r = 3,   ... )

title: Heatcircle — geom_heat_circle
text: outside column name outside portion heatcircle. outside_name label name (quotes) legend outside rendering. Default NULL. outside_colors color vector, usually hex codes. inside column name inside portion heatcircle. inside_name label name (quotes) legend inside rendering. Default NULL. inside_colors color vector, usually hex codes. r value controls large inside portion respect outside one. r larger, inside get smaller. Default value 3. ... ... accepts arguments scale_fill_gradientn() .

title: Heatcircle — geom_heat_circle
text: heatcircle comparing two data sources.

title: Heatcircle — geom_heat_circle
code: # heatcircle with categorical variables only  library(ggplot2)  data <- data.frame(x = rep(c("a", "b", "c"), 3),                    y = rep(c("d", "e", "f"), 3),                    outside_values = rep(c(1,5,7),3),                    inside_values = rep(c(2,3,4),3))  ggplot(data, aes(x,y)) + geom_heat_circle(outside = outside_values,                  inside = inside_values)    # Making the inside smaller by setting r to be larger.  ggplot(data, aes(x,y)) + geom_heat_circle(outside = outside_values,                  inside = inside_values,                  r = 5)    # heatcircle with numeric variables only  data <- data.frame(x = rep(c(1, 2, 3), 3),                    y = rep(c(1, 2, 3), 3),                    outside_values = rep(c(1,5,7),3),                    inside_values = rep(c(2,3,4),3))  ggplot(data, aes(x,y)) + geom_heat_circle(outside = outside_values,                  inside = inside_values)    # heatcircle with a mixture of numeric and categorical variables  data <- data.frame(x = rep(c("a", "b", "c"), 3),                    y = rep(c(1, 2, 3), 3),                    outside_values = rep(c(1,5,7),3),                    inside_values = rep(c(2,3,4),3))  ggplot(data, aes(x,y)) + geom_heat_circle(outside = outside_values,                  inside = inside_values)

title: Heatgrid — geom_heat_grid
text: heatgrid geom used create modified heat map uses luminance show values two sources plot.

title: Heatgrid — geom_heat_grid
code: geom_heat_grid(   outside,   outside_name = NULL,   outside_colors = c("#FED7D8", "#FE8C91", "#F5636B", "#E72D3F", "#C20824"),   inside,   inside_name = NULL,   inside_colors = c("gray100", "gray85", "gray50", "gray35", "gray0"),   r = 3,   ... )

title: Heatgrid — geom_heat_grid
text: outside column name outside portion heatgrid. outside_name label name (quotes) legend outside rendering. Default NULL. outside_colors color vector, usually hex codes. inside column name inside portion heatgrid. inside_name label name (quotes) legend inside rendering. Default NULL. inside_colors color vector, usually hex codes. r value controls large inside portion respect outside one. r larger, inside get smaller. Default value 3. ... ... accepts arguments scale_fill_gradientn() .

title: Heatgrid — geom_heat_grid
text: heatgrid comparing two data sources.

title: Heatgrid — geom_heat_grid
code: # heatgrid with categorical variables only  library(ggplot2)  data <- data.frame(x = rep(c("a", "b", "c"), 3),                    y = rep(c("d", "e", "f"), 3),                    outside_values = rep(c(1,5,7),3),                    inside_values = rep(c(2,3,4),3))  ggplot(data, aes(x,y)) + geom_heat_grid(outside = outside_values,                inside = inside_values)   # Making the inside smaller by setting r to be larger.  ggplot(data, aes(x,y)) + geom_heat_grid(outside = outside_values,                inside = inside_values,                r = 5)   # heatgrid with numeric variables only  data <- data.frame(x = rep(c(1, 2, 3), 3),                    y = rep(c(1, 2, 3), 3),                    outside_values = rep(c(1,5,7),3),                    inside_values = rep(c(2,3,4),3))  ggplot(data, aes(x,y)) + geom_heat_grid(outside = outside_values,                inside = inside_values)    # heatgrid with a mixture of numeric and categorical variables  data <- data.frame(x = rep(c("a", "b", "c"), 3),                    y = rep(c(1, 2, 3), 3),                    outside_values = rep(c(1,5,7),3),                    inside_values = rep(c(2,3,4),3))  ggplot(data, aes(x,y)) + geom_heat_grid(outside = outside_values,                inside = inside_values)

title: Heattriangle — geom_heat_tri
text: heattriangle geom used create two triangles split diagonal line rectangle use luminance show values two sources plot.

title: Heattriangle — geom_heat_tri
code: geom_heat_tri(   lower,   lower_name = NULL,   lower_colors = c("#FED7D8", "#FE8C91", "#F5636B", "#E72D3F", "#C20824"),   upper,   upper_name = NULL,   upper_colors = c("gray100", "gray85", "gray50", "gray35", "gray0"),   ... )

title: Heattriangle — geom_heat_tri
text: lower column name lower portion heattriangle. lower_name label name (quotes) legend lower rendering. Default NULL. lower_colors color vector, usually hex codes. upper column name upper portion heattriangle. upper_name label name (quotes) legend upper rendering. Default NULL. upper_colors color vector, usually hex codes. ... ... accepts arguments scale_fill_gradientn() .

title: Heattriangle — geom_heat_tri
text: heattriangle main diagonal split line within unit.

title: Heattriangle — geom_heat_tri
code: # heattriangle with categorical variables only  library(ggplot2)  data <- data.frame(x = rep(c("a", "b", "c"), 3),                    y = rep(c("d", "e", "f"), 3),                    lower_values = rep(c(1,5,7),3),                    upper_values = rep(c(2,3,4),3))  ggplot(data, aes(x,y)) + geom_heat_tri(lower = lower_values, upper = upper_values)    # heatcircle with numeric variables only  data <- data.frame(x = rep(c(1, 2, 3), 3),                    y = rep(c(1, 2, 3), 3),                    lower_values = rep(c(1,5,7),3),                    upper_values = rep(c(2,3,4),3))  ggplot(data, aes(x,y)) + geom_heat_tri(lower = lower_values, upper = upper_values)    # heatcircle with a mixture of numeric and categorical variables  data <- data.frame(x = rep(c("a", "b", "c"), 3),                    y = rep(c(1, 2, 3), 3),                    lower_values = rep(c(1,5,7),3),                    upper_values = rep(c(2,3,4),3))  ggplot(data, aes(x,y)) + geom_heat_tri(lower = lower_values, upper = upper_values)

what: ggDoubleHeat: Data visualization for two sources — ggDoubleHeat
title: ggDoubleHeat: Data visualization for two sources — ggDoubleHeat
text: ggDoubleHeat, ggplot2 extension, provides visualization reformed heatmap. Instead facetting heatmaps data sources, can combined together making one single heatmap, generated geom_heat_*() functions built package. Prior using package, users load ggplot2.

title: ggDoubleHeat: Data visualization for two sources — ggDoubleHeat
text: functions package named geom_heat_*(), making naming convention consistent. Also, arguments functions relatively similar, although slight variations due specific argument connect position rendering plot. Users reference documentation possibly run examples presented help file trying understand argument means visually.

title: Popular Emojis — pitts_emojis
text: popular Emoji given week given category Meltwater Tweet sample. can rendered using "richtext" annotate().

title: Popular Emojis — pitts_emojis
text: object class character length 270.

what: Pittsburgh COVID-related Google & Twitter incidence rates — pitts_tg
title: Pittsburgh COVID-related Google & Twitter incidence rates — pitts_tg
text: data set containing 30-week incidence rates COVID related categories week 1 starting June 1, 2020 week 30 ended last Sunday year Pittsburgh Metropolitan Statistical Area (MSA). data columns introduced . One quick note columns data set: week_start column present data set illustration purposes, reminding users week column . words, participate visualization.

title: Pittsburgh COVID-related Google & Twitter incidence rates — pitts_tg
Pittsburgh COVID-related Google & Twitter incidence rates — pitts_tg
text: data frame 270 rows 6 columns: msa Metropolitan statistical area (Pittsburgh ). week week 1 week 30. week_start Monday date week started. category 9 Covid-related categories total. Twitter weekly tweets percentage (%) MSA falling   category. Google weekly Google search percentage (%) MSA falling   category.

title: Pittsburgh COVID-related Google & Twitter incidence rates — pitts_tg
text: Just like states_tg, Google processed Google Health API, Twitter Meltwater, Twitter vendor. data sources processed authors package.

title: Remove ggplot2 default padding — remove_padding
text: default ggplot2 plots give certain amount padding continuous discrete variables. Due padding, makes plots generated `geom_heat_*()` look like something missing. Depends users' preference, can remove "empty space" using function. thing users need figure whether `x` `y` scales continuous discrete.

text: x x-axis scale, continuous scale, input "c"; discrete, "d". y y-axis scale, continuous scale, input "c"; discrete, "d". ... ...
